layers_all.caption: Text "When done legally in industrialized societies, induced abortion is one of the safest procedures in medicine. In the United States, the risk of maternal mortality is 14 times lower after induced abortion than after childbirth." in <color-57>, <en-font-476>.

layers_all.caption: The image is an infographic titled 'Understanding the Ampere' with a focus on electrical units and scientific history. The infographic includes icons such as electrons, wires, and historical figures, along with charts and timelines to visually support the content. This design aims to educate and inform, making complex scientific concepts accessible to a broad audience.
Figure A stylized electric current flowing through a wire, with electrons represented as small blue dots moving in a straight line, and the ampere symbol (A) displayed prominently near the flow.
Figure A timeline showing the historical development of the ampere, with key dates such as 1881 (International Exposition of Electricity) and 2019 (redefinition of SI units).

A decorative element or icon.
A decorative element or icon.

Text "The ampere (A), often shortened to amp, is the unit of electric current in the International System of Units (SI). One ampere is equal to 1 coulomb moving past a point in 1 second." in <color-28>, <en-font-123>.
layers_all.text: The ampere (A), often shortened to amp, is the unit of electric current in the International System of Units (SI). One ampere is equal to 1 coulomb moving past a point in 1 second.

layers_all.caption: Text "As of the 2019 redefinition of the SI base units, the ampere is defined by fixing the elementary charge to be exactly 1.602176634×10⁻¹⁹ coulombs, which means an ampere is an electric current equivalent to 1 coulomb moving per second." in <color-79>, <en-font-123>.
layers_all.text: As of the 2019 redefinition of the SI base units, the ampere is defined by fixing the elementary charge to be exactly 1.602176634×10⁻¹⁹ coulombs, which means an ampere is an electric current equivalent to 1 coulomb moving per second.

layers_all.caption: Text "Prior to the redefinition, the ampere was defined as the current passing through 2 parallel wires 1 metre apart that produces a magnetic force of 2×10⁻⁷ newtons per metre." in <color-79>, <en-font-123>.
layers_all.text: Prior to the redefinition, the ampere was defined as the current passing through 2 parallel wires 1 metre apart that produces a magnetic force of 2×10⁻⁷ newtons per metre.

layers_all.caption: Text "The ampere is named for French physicist and mathematician André-Marie Ampère (1775–1836), who studied electromagnetism and laid the foundation of electrodynamics." in <color-79>, <en-font-123>.
layers_all.text: The ampere is named for French physicist and mathematician André-Marie Ampère (1775–1836), who studied electromagnetism and laid the foundation of electrodynamics.

layers_all.caption: The image is an infographic titled 'Asparagales: The Evolution and Classification of a Monocot Order' with a focus on plant taxonomy and evolutionary biology. The design style is educational and minimalist, with a clean, modern layout that emphasizes clarity and visual storytelling. The color palette is primarily blue and green, symbolizing growth, science, and the natural world, with white and gray accents for contrast and readability. The infographic includes symbolic graphics such as phylogenetic trees, molecular sequence diagrams, and botanical illustrations of key species like Allium. The purpose is to educate and inform about the recent classification updates and the significance of Asparagales in the broader context of monocot evolution.

Figure A stylized phylogenetic tree showing the classification of Asparagales, with branches indicating the evolution from Liliales to the modern order, including key families like Asparagaceae and Alliaceae.
Figure A comparison of telomere sequences across Asparagales, showing the evolution from TTTAGGG to TTAGGG and finally to CTCGGTTATGGG in Allium, highlighting genetic divergence.
Figure An illustration of key Asparagales species, such as Allium (onion), Aloe, and Agave, showing their morphological diversity and ecological roles.
Figure A timeline showing the historical classification of Asparagales, from the old Liliales order to the modern APG circumscription, with key dates and researchers highlighted.
A decorative element or icon.
A decorative element or icon.
A decorative element or icon.

Text "Asparagales is an order of monocots that was first proposed in 1977 and later adopted in the APG classification systems. It includes over 36,000 species across 14 families." in <color-89>, <en-font-10>.
layers_all.text: Asparagales is an order of monocots that was first proposed in 1977 and later adopted in the APG classification systems. It includes over 36,000 species across 14 families.

layers_all.caption: Text "The order is defined by the presence of phytomelanin, a black pigment in seed coats, and structural diversity, including herbaceous perennials, climbers, and geophytes like bulbs and tubers." in <color-89>, <en-font-10>.
layers_all.text: The order is defined by the presence of phytomelanin, a black pigment in seed coats, and structural diversity, including herbaceous perennials, climbers, and geophytes like bulbs and tubers.

layers_all.caption: Text "Asparagales is the largest monocot order, with ongoing research leading to potential future changes in its classification and family boundaries." in <color-89>, <en-font-10>.
layers_all.text: Asparagales is the largest monocot order, with ongoing research leading to potential future changes in its classification and family boundaries.

layers_all.caption: Text "Molecular phylogenetics has clarified the boundaries of Asparagales, though morphological diversity makes it challenging to define based on physical traits alone." in <color-72>, <en-font-10>.
layers_all.text: Molecular phylogenetics has clarified the boundaries of Asparagales, though morphological diversity makes it challenging to define based on physical traits alone.

layers_all.caption: The image is an infographic titled 'The Apiales Order: A Botanical Journey' with a focus on plant taxonomy and evolutionary relationships. The design style is educational and minimalist, using a clean, modern layout with a muted color palette of soft greens, earthy browns, and neutral whites. The visual tone is informative and scientific, suitable for an audience of botanists, students, and nature enthusiasts. The layout is horizontally structured to guide the viewer from left to right, mimicking the flow of taxonomic classification and evolutionary progression. The left side introduces the order Apiales with key plant species, the center section details the phylogenetic relationships and classification systems, and the right side focuses on the reproductive structures, specifically gynoecia, with comparative visuals. The infographic uses icons representing plant species, flowcharts for classification, and symbolic graphics like DNA strands and phylogenetic trees. The intended purpose is to educate and inform the viewer on the taxonomy, evolution, and reproductive biology of the Apiales order, emphasizing the importance of molecular data in modern classification systems.
Figure A stylized illustration of the Apiales order, showing key plant species like carrots, celery, parsley, and ivy, arranged in a circular formation with DNA strands in the background.
Figure A simplified phylogenetic tree showing the placement of Apiales within the asterids, campanulids, and Apiidae clade, with branching subclades like Dipsapiidae.
Figure A comparison chart between the Cronquist system and APG III system, showing the evolution of classification with icons for each system and their respective groupings.

Text "The Apiales are an order of flowering plants, including well-known species such as carrots, celery, parsley, and English ivy." in <color-127>, <en-font-17>.
layers_all.text: The Apiales are an order of flowering plants, including well-known species such as carrots, celery, parsley, and English ivy.

layers_all.caption: Text "Under the APG III system, Apiales is classified within the asterid group as part of the campanulids and the clade Apiidae, which includes subclades like Dipsapiidae." in <color-123>, <en-font-17>.
layers_all.text: Under the APG III system, Apiales is classified within the asterid group as part of the campanulids and the clade Apiidae, which includes subclades like Dipsapiidae.

layers_all.caption: Text "The Cronquist system classified only Apiaceae and Araliaceae, while the APG III system includes more families and reflects molecular data." in <color-116>, <en-font-17>.
layers_all.text: The Cronquist system classified only Apiaceae and Araliaceae, while the APG III system includes more families and reflects molecular data.

layers_all.caption: Text "The gynoecia of Apiales families exhibit four zones of carpel fusion, with the synascidiate and symplicate zones being fertile and ovule-bearing." in <color-123>, <en-font-17>.
layers_all.text: The gynoecia of Apiales families exhibit four zones of carpel fusion, with the synascidiate and symplicate zones being fertile and ovule-bearing.

layers_all.caption: Text "Although the name applies to a group of snakes, it is often used to refer only to one species, in particular, the common or green anaconda (Eunectes murinus), which is the largest snake in the world by weight, and the second longest after the reticulated python." in <color-99>, <en-font-453>.

layers_all.caption: Text "The name anaconda is derived from a snake from Ceylon (Sri Lanka) that John Ray described in Latin in his 1693 work, with later contributions from Henry Yule and Frank Wall." in <color-59>, <en-font-453>.

layers_all.caption: The image is an infographic titled 'Understanding the Axiom of Choice' with a focus on mathematics and set theory. The design style is educational and minimalist, with a clean layout and a muted color palette of blues, whites, and soft grays to reflect clarity and intellectual rigor. The visual tone is informative and analytical, aimed at students and educators interested in foundational mathematics. The infographic is structured for a wide horizontal layout, following a left-to-right flow that mirrors the logical progression of the topic. The left side introduces the concept with a symbolic representation of the axiom, the center elaborates on its formal definition and examples, and the right side explores its implications and paradoxes. The layout includes a series of icons, such as a Cartesian plane, a set of abstract shapes, and a mathematical formula, alongside explanatory text blocks. The intended audience is primarily students and scholars of mathematics, with the purpose of demystifying a complex but foundational concept in set theory.
Figure A Cartesian plane with a collection of non-empty sets represented as circles, each containing a few numbers or symbols, illustrating the concept of a Cartesian product.
Figure A set of abstract shapes (circles, squares, triangles) with arrows pointing to selected elements, visually representing the process of choosing one element from each set.
Figure A comparison between two scenarios: one with a defined choice function (e.g., selecting the smallest number) and one where the axiom of choice is necessary (e.g., subsets of real numbers).
Figure A symbolic representation of the well-ordering theorem, with a chain of elements showing how AC enables the ordering of any set.
A decorative element or icon.
A decorative element or icon.

Text "The Axiom of Choice (AC) states that given any collection of non-empty sets, it is possible to construct a new set by selecting one element from each set, even if the collection is infinite." in <color-110>, <en-font-230>.
layers_all.text: The Axiom of Choice (AC) states that given any collection of non-empty sets, it is possible to construct a new set by selecting one element from each set, even if the collection is infinite.

layers_all.caption: Text "Formally, for every indexed family of nonempty sets, there exists an indexed set such that for every i, the chosen element is from the i-th set." in <color-31>, <en-font-230>.
layers_all.text: Formally, for every indexed family of nonempty sets, there exists an indexed set such that for every i, the chosen element is from the i-th set.

layers_all.caption: Text "In cases with a canonical rule (e.g., selecting the smallest number), a choice function can be defined without invoking AC. However, for arbitrary non-empty sets, AC is required." in <color-110>, <en-font-230>.
layers_all.text: In cases with a canonical rule (e.g., selecting the smallest number), a choice function can be defined without invoking AC. However, for arbitrary non-empty sets, AC is required.

layers_all.caption: Text "Bertrand Russell's analogy: for pairs of shoes, one can always choose the left shoe, but for socks (no distinguishing feature), AC is necessary to define a choice function." in <color-110>, <en-font-230>.
layers_all.text: Bertrand Russell's analogy: for pairs of shoes, one can always choose the left shoe, but for socks (no distinguishing feature), AC is necessary to define a choice function.

Text "Alfred Elton van Vogt (April 26, 1912 – January 26, 2000) was a Canadian-born American science fiction author whose fragmented, bizarre narrative style influenced later writers like Philip K. Dick." in <color-36>, <en-font-71>.

layers_all.caption: Text "Born in Manitoba, Canada, van Vogt moved frequently as a child and worked as a farmhand and truck driver before pursuing writing. He sold his first story in 1932 and gained recognition for his unique storytelling style." in <color-36>, <en-font-71>.

layers_all.caption: Text "The Science Fiction Writers of America named him their 14th Grand Master in 1995, recognizing his complex and influential contributions to the genre during its Golden Age." in <color-36>, <en-font-71>.
layers_all.text: The Science Fiction Writers of America named him their 14th Grand Master in 1995, recognizing his complex and influential contributions to the genre during its Golden Age.

layers_all.caption: Text "Van Vogt's early works were published anonymously in true confession-style magazines, showcasing his ability to blend personal narrative with speculative fiction." in <color-132>, <en-font-71>.

layers_all.caption: Text "Nearly all of the argon in Earth's atmosphere is radiogenic argon-40, derived from the decay of potassium-40 in Earth's crust." in <color-100>, <en-font-129>.
layers_all.text: Nearly all of the argon in Earth's atmosphere is radiogenic argon-40, derived from the decay of potassium-40 in Earth's crust.

layers_all.caption: Text "The name 'argon' is derived from the Greek word 'argos' meaning 'lazy' or 'inactive', as a reference to the fact that the element undergoes almost no chemical reactions." in <color-11>, <en-font-129>.
layers_all.text: The name 'argon' is derived from the Greek word 'argos' meaning 'lazy' or 'inactive', as a reference to the fact that the element undergoes almost no chemical reactions.

layers_all.caption: Text "Argon is extracted industrially by the fractional distillation of liquid air. It is used as an inert shielding gas in welding and other high-temperature processes." in <color-100>, <en-font-129>.
layers_all.text: Argon is extracted industrially by the fractional distillation of liquid air. It is used as an inert shielding gas in welding and other high-temperature processes.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled 'Argon: The Inert Element' with a focus on chemistry and atmospheric science. The infographic adopts a clean, minimalist design style with a cool, scientific color palette of blues, whites, and greys, evoking a sense of precision and clarity. The layout is horizontally structured to guide the viewer from left to right, mirroring the natural flow of information about the element’s properties, abundance, and applications. The left side features a visual representation of the periodic table, highlighting argon’s position in group 18. The center section presents a comparison of argon’s abundance in the atmosphere and crust, using bar charts and percentages. The right side showcases argon’s industrial uses, including its role in welding and lighting, with icons representing these applications. The visual hierarchy places the periodic table at the far left, the data comparisons at the center, and the real-world applications at the far right. The infographic uses icons like gas cylinders, welding torches, and lightbulbs, along with symbolic graphics such as atomic structures and temperature scales. The intended audience is students and educators, with the purpose of providing an informative and visually engaging overview of argon’s properties and significance in both scientific and industrial contexts.

layers_all.caption: The image is an infographic titled 'Arsenic: The Dual-Edged Element' with a focus on the chemical element arsenic. The design style is educational and informative, with a clean, minimalist aesthetic that emphasizes clarity and visual hierarchy. The color palette uses muted tones of blue, green, and grey to evoke a scientific and neutral tone, while accent colors like red and orange are used to highlight toxicity and danger. The infographic is designed for a wide horizontal layout, spanning 2240×896 pixels, with a balanced composition that guides the viewer from left to right, creating a natural flow of information. At the far left, a central figure of arsenic’s atomic structure is depicted, symbolizing its fundamental nature. The center section highlights its industrial and technological uses, such as in semiconductors and alloys, while the right side emphasizes its toxic effects and environmental impact. The visual elements include atomic diagrams, molecular structures, charts showing toxicity levels, and symbolic graphics like a contaminated water droplet and a warning sign. The intended audience is primarily students, researchers, and environmental professionals, with the purpose of educating on arsenic’s properties, uses, and dangers. The infographic aims to be both informative and visually engaging, encouraging awareness and responsible handling of this element.
Figure A central atomic structure of arsenic with the symbol As and atomic number 33, surrounded by a hexagonal lattice representing its metallic allotrope.
Figure A side-by-side comparison of arsenic’s allotropes: grey, yellow, and black, with labels indicating their physical properties and uses.
Figure A flowchart showing the use of arsenic in various industries, including pesticides, treated wood, and electronics, with arrows indicating its applications and decline due to toxicity concerns.
Figure A map highlighting regions with arsenic-contaminated groundwater, alongside a graph showing the rise in arsenic-related health risks and its classification as a Group-A carcinogen.

Text "Arsenic is a chemical element with the symbol As and atomic number 33. It is a metalloid found in minerals and as a pure elemental crystal, with the grey form being the most industrially significant." in <color-106>, <en-font-76>.
layers_all.text: Arsenic is a chemical element with the symbol As and atomic number 33. It is a metalloid found in minerals and as a pure elemental crystal, with the grey form being the most industrially significant.

layers_all.caption: Text "The grey form of arsenic is used in alloys, semiconductors, and electronics, while its toxic properties make it a serious environmental and health concern." in <color-106>, <en-font-76>.
layers_all.text: The grey form of arsenic is used in alloys, semiconductors, and electronics, while its toxic properties make it a serious environmental and health concern.

layers_all.caption: Text "Arsenic and its compounds are used in pesticides, treated wood, and electronics, but their use is declining due to growing awareness of their toxicity and environmental impact." in <color-41>, <en-font-76>.
layers_all.text: Arsenic and its compounds are used in pesticides, treated wood, and electronics, but their use is declining due to growing awareness of their toxicity and environmental impact.

layers_all.caption: Text "Arsenic contamination of groundwater affects millions globally, and it is classified as a Group-A carcinogen by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, posing serious health risks." in <color-5>, <en-font-76>.
layers_all.text: Arsenic contamination of groundwater affects millions globally, and it is classified as a Group-A carcinogen by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, posing serious health risks.

layers_all.caption: The image is an infographic titled 'Antimony: The Metalloid with a Rich History' with a focus on the chemical element antimony. The design style is educational and minimalist, with a clean, modern layout that emphasizes clarity and visual storytelling. The color palette features a combination of deep blues, metallic grays, and warm golds, reflecting both the scientific and historical aspects of the subject. The visual tone is informative yet engaging, blending factual data with historical context to appeal to both students and professionals. The layout is designed for a 2240×896 horizontal format, with information flowing from left to right in a balanced, side-by-side composition. At the far left, a symbolic representation of antimony in nature is featured, with the center section highlighting its properties and applications, and the right side focusing on its industrial and modern uses. The infographic includes icons of atoms, mines, chemical formulas, and historical artifacts, along with charts and symbolic graphics to enhance understanding. The intended audience is a broad range of readers, from chemistry students to general science enthusiasts, with the purpose of providing a comprehensive overview of antimony’s history, properties, and uses.
Figure A lustrous gray metalloid antimony crystal with a close-up view of its atomic structure and a small icon of a mine in the background.
Figure A historical illustration of ancient kohl application with a stylized Arabic script and a powder icon representing its use in medicine and cosmetics.
Figure A map of China with a highlighted Xikuangshan Mine in Hunan and a chart showing the industrial refining process of antimony.
Figure A schematic diagram of antimony’s applications in alloys, batteries, and flame retardants, with icons representing each use.

A decorative element or icon.

Text "Antimony is a chemical element with the symbol Sb and atomic number 51. A lustrous gray metalloid, it is found in nature mainly as the sulfide mineral stibnite (Sb₂S₃)." in <color-11>, <en-font-240>.
layers_all.text: Antimony is a chemical element with the symbol Sb and atomic number 51. A lustrous gray metalloid, it is found in nature mainly as the sulfide mineral stibnite (Sb₂S₃).

layers_all.caption: Text "Antimony compounds have been known since ancient times and were powdered for use as medicine and cosmetics, often known by the Arabic name kohl. The earliest known description of the metalloid in the West was written in 1540 by Vannoccio Biringuccio." in <color-126>, <en-font-240>.
layers_all.text: Antimony compounds have been known since ancient times and were powdered for use as medicine and cosmetics, often known by the Arabic name kohl. The earliest known description of the metalloid in the West was written in 1540 by Vannoccio Biringuccio.

layers_all.caption: Text "China is the largest producer of antimony and its compounds, with most production coming from the Xikuangshan Mine in Hunan. The industrial methods for refining antimony from stibnite are roasting followed by reduction with carbon, or direct reduction of stibnite with iron." in <color-83>, <en-font-240>.
layers_all.text: China is the largest producer of antimony and its compounds, with most production coming from the Xikuangshan Mine in Hunan. The industrial methods for refining antimony from stibnite are roasting followed by reduction with carbon, or direct reduction of stibnite with iron.

layers_all.caption: Text "The largest applications for metallic antimony are in alloys with lead and tin, which have improved properties for solders, bullets, and plain bearings. It improves the rigidity of lead-alloy plates in lead–acid batteries. Antimony trioxide is a prominent additive for halogen-containing flame retardants. Antimony is used as a dopant in semiconductor devices." in <color-19>, <en-font-240>.
layers_all.text: The largest applications for metallic antimony are in alloys with lead and tin, which have improved properties for solders, bullets, and plain bearings. It improves the rigidity of lead-alloy plates in lead–acid batteries. Antimony trioxide is a prominent additive for halogen-containing flame retardants. Antimony is used as a dopant in semiconductor devices.
